Added in 14ea26d.

content.raw: Added in 11a6247. I left out `//world/joint` for now.
content.html: Added in 11a6247. I left out //world/joint for now.

content.raw: Can you elaborate on what you mean by this? We have not addressed the behavior of `//model/pose[@relative_to]` so far, but following that `relative_to` must lead to the world frame. So maybe we should in general say that following the `relative_to` attributes must ultimately lead to the world frame.
content.html: Can you elaborate on what you mean by this? We have not addressed the behavior of //model/pose[@relative_to] so far, but following that relative_to must lead to the world frame. So maybe we should in general say that following the relative_to attributes must ultimately lead to the world frame.

content.raw: I would say yes, but I would not talk about `//world/joint` at all until nesting because there are no sibling `//world/link` elements to declare as parent or child.
content.html: I would say yes, but I would not talk about //world/joint at all until nesting because there are no sibling //world/link elements to declare as parent or child.

content.raw: How about attaching `//world/frame` to `//world/joint`, should that be allowed? Or should we punt on `//world/joint` until nesting?
content.html: How about attaching //world/frame to //world/joint, should that be allowed? Or should we punt on //world/joint until nesting?

content.raw: Since the model frame is now well defined, I don't see a problem with letting `//world/frame` be attached to a model frame. I'll add it in.
content.html: Since the model frame is now well defined, I don't see a problem with letting //world/frame be attached to a model frame. I'll add it in.

content.raw: I would treat `//world/model/pose[@relative_to]` in a similar manner to `//world/frame/pose[@relative_to]`
content.html: I would treat //world/model/pose[@relative_to] in a similar manner to //world/frame/pose[@relative_to]

content.raw: could a `//world/frame` be attached_to a sibling model frame?
content.html: could a //world/frame be attached_to a sibling model frame?

content.raw: Could we be more explicit and say that sibling frames `//world/frame` and `//world/model` (and `//world/joint` if that became a thing) must have unique names?
content.html: Could we be more explicit and say that sibling frames //world/frame and //world/model (and //world/joint if that became a thing) must have unique names?
Done. 9c8143b

content.raw: Yeah, I left that out on purpose. We can come back and address it once we nail down nesting semantics.
content.html: Yeah, I left that out on purpose. We can come back and address it once we nail down nesting semantics.

content.raw:
Does this mean that a user can't define `//world`-scoped frame that is attached to a model’s link or any other defined frame? \(e.g. it can’t dig in?\)

If this depends on nesting semantics, I guess that could then open this up to allow drilling?
content.html:
Does this mean that a user can't define //world-scoped frame that is attached to a model’s link or any other defined frame? (e.g. it can’t dig in?)

If this depends on nesting semantics, I guess that could then open this up to allow drilling?
nit Grammar “is given” => “are given”
